metadata.notes: Fifteenth Sunday after Pentecost, Year C. Focuses on the Parable of the Dishonest Manager.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. The preacher largely avoids 'shaming' the listener, instead critiquing systems and 'bottom-line' thinking.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: Coercion is minimal. The preacher uses 'we' and 'us' to include himself in the struggle rather than pointing a finger from above.
quotes: I will not try to make this easy for us.
I assume you are like me, something of a Presbyterian who must make up our minds afresh.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. The preacher offers a 'fallback' for a frightening future without being overly sentimental.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The care is supportive of autonomy; it encourages the listener to build their own social safety nets through generosity.
quotes: Jeremiah only asks, 'Is there a balm in Gilead?'

adult.score_explanation: 10 = Strong Adult presence. The sermon is highly analytical, testing the parable against the 'reality' of modern economics and social structures.
adult.analysis: The preacher addresses the listener as a thinking subject capable of navigating a complex, 'hard' teaching. He uses historical and social data (industrialism, military power) to ground the text.
quotes: As he thinks about what to do, he recognizes that he is not strong enough to do manual labor...
The children of light are the good folks who play by the rules... In a word, they are good Presbyterians.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. The sermon acknowledges fear (when things are gone) but doesn't use it to demand submission to the preacher.
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher admits his own 'Presbyterian' tendencies toward compliance, modeling a move away from the Adapted Child role.
quotes: I assume you are like me...

free_child_FC.score_explanation: 10 = Authentic, playful, joyful. There is an intellectual playfulness in 'cooking the books' for God.
free_child_FC.analysis: The 'Free Child' appears in the endorsement of 'shrewdness,' 'cunning,' and 'imagination' over rigid rules.
quotes: step out of the box, cook the books, be shrewd, make friends.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher invites the congregation into a shared reflection on a difficult text. He avoids the typical Parent-Child dynamic of 'I have the truth, you must obey.'
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: There is a slight psychological push to move the listener from 'Presbyterian' (Adapted Child/Critical Parent) to 'Shrewd Manager' (Adult/Free Child).
transaction_analysis.purity_explanation: 10 = Completely transparent. The preacher is very open about the difficulty of the text and his own position within the critique.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The only risk is a subtle 'Ain't It Awful' regarding the decline of industrialism/privilege, but it is used to prompt Adult action rather than Child passivity.

games_analysis.absence_of_games_analysis: The sermon avoids games by maintaining an Adult-Adult stance. It doesn't promise a 'simple solution' (Con) to avoid the 'Switch.' Instead, it presents a 'hard, radical teaching' and leaves the choice to the listener.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Low. He doesn't offer to save the congregation; he points to the need for them to make friends.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low. Even the critique of 'white male privilege' is framed as a reality to be navigated rather than a sin to be punished.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. He identifies with the 'man in the middle' but does not act helpless.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is invited to be the 'Manager'—an Adult role that must make choices between two systems.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: The sermon is an escape route from the Triangle. It moves from the Victimhood of 'when it is gone' to the Autonomy of 'shrewdness' and 'generosity.'

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: This sermon is psychologically robust and remarkably free of manipulative 'games.' By speaking from an Adult ego position, the preacher respects the autonomy of the listeners. He avoids the 'Critical Parent' trap of moralizing the parable and instead uses 'Structural Analysis' to compare two worldviews (God vs. Mammon). The preacher’s self-inclusion ('I assume you are like me') prevents a hierarchical Parent-Child transaction, fostering a space for authentic reflection.
strengths: Avoidance of shaming or coercive language.
Honest acknowledgment of the 'hard' nature of the text.
areas_for_improvement: The section on 'when it is gone' could briefly trigger a 'Victim' response in listeners if not balanced with more 'Free Child' hope.
The 'Presbyterian' label is a mild stereotype that could be perceived as a 'Critical Parent' judgment by some.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Continue to use 'we' and 'us' to maintain the Adult-Adult contract. Ensure that the 'Free Child's' joy and creativity are emphasized as much as the 'Adult's' shrewdness to prevent the sermon from becoming purely intellectual.
